hints_raw:
Recall the definition of the gradient:
:<math>
\nabla H(x,y) = \left\langle \frac{\partial H}{\partial x}(x,y), \frac{\partial H}{\partial y}(x,y) \right\rangle
</math>

To use [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH105/April 2012/Question 05 (a)|part (a)]], write ''H'' in terms of ''F'' and ''G''.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
We write H as a sum of F and G:

\[\begin{aligned} H(x,y) = \int_y^0 \ln(2 + \sin t) dt + \int_0^x \ln(2 + \sin t) dt = G(y) + F(x).\end{aligned}\]

Then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H_x = \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(F(x)+G(y)) = F'(x) + 0 = \ln(2+\sin(x))\end{aligned}\]

and similarly

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H_y = \frac{\partial}{\partial y}(F(x)+G(y)) = 0 + G'(y) = -\ln(2+\sin(y))\end{aligned}\]

where we used the knowledge about the derivatives F’(x) and G’(y) from part (a). Finally, all that is left to do is to plug in the given values to find that

\[\begin{aligned} \nabla H\left(\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = \left\langle F'\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right), G'\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) \right\rangle = \langle \ln 3, -\ln 3\rangle\end{aligned}\]

Now define

\[\begin{aligned} H(x,y) = \int_y^x \ln(2+\sin t)\,dt.\end{aligned}\]

Find the first partial derivatives of H and use this to compute \(\displaystyle \nabla H\left(\frac{\pi}2,\frac{\pi}2\right)\).
